<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 186, 171, 201]]<|/det|>
# PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 207, 279, 222]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Multiple Choice  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 186, 907, 202]]<|/det|>
0625/11  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 208, 907, 223]]<|/det|>
May/June 2013  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[814, 229, 907, 243]]<|/det|>
45 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 248, 590, 293]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Multiple Choice Answer Sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 312, 388, 329]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 343, 235, 358]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 358, 599, 373]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 373, 892, 403]]<|/det|>
Write your name, Centre number and candidate number on the Answer Sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 400, 383, 416]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 430, 892, 460]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions. For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 459, 890, 475]]<|/det|>
Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the separate Answer Sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 488, 556, 505]]<|/det|>
Read the instructions on the Answer Sheet very carefully.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 518, 764, 534]]<|/det|>
Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 534, 467, 549]]<|/det|>
Any rough working should be done in this booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 549, 359, 564]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 816, 106]]<|/det|> The diagrams show the readings on a measuring cylinder before and after a small added. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[215, 114, 781, 325]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 339, 920, 375]]<|/det|> How many more identical cubes can be added to the cylinder, without causing the water to overflow? Do not include the cube already in the cylinder. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 382, 133, 400]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 382, 168, 400]]<|/det|> 1 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 382, 298, 400]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[313, 382, 333, 400]]<|/det|> 2 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 382, 468, 400]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[473, 382, 492, 400]]<|/det|> 3 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 382, 635, 400]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[640, 382, 668, 400]]<|/det|> 4 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 426, 97, 445]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 426, 504, 445]]<|/det|> Which person is experiencing an acceleration? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 456, 133, 475]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 456, 584, 475]]<|/det|> a driver of a car that is braking to stop at traffic lights <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 482, 133, 501]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 482, 631, 501]]<|/det|> a passenger in a train that is stationary in a railway station <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 508, 133, 526]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 508, 828, 526]]<|/det|> a shopper in a large store ascending an escalator (moving stairs) at a uniform rate <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 534, 133, 552]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 534, 594, 552]]<|/det|> a skydiver falling at constant speed towards the Earth <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 579, 97, 597]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 579, 562, 597]]<|/det|> A car travels at various speeds during a short journey. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 609, 920, 643]]<|/det|> The table shows the distances travelled and the times taken during each of four stages P, Q, R and S. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 653, 816, 732]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 803, 92]]<|/det|>
Two blocks of metal X and Y hang from spring balances, as shown in the diagrams.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[349, 98, 645, 419]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 429, 494, 450]]<|/det|>
What does the diagram show about X and Y?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 459, 134, 477]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 459, 730, 479]]<|/det|>
They have the same mass and the same volume but different weights.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 485, 133, 504]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 485, 730, 504]]<|/det|>
They have the same mass and the same weight but different volumes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 510, 133, 530]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 510, 705, 530]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 537, 133, 555]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 537, 742, 555]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 583, 96, 602]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 581, 920, 616]]<|/det|>
A \(1\mathrm{kg}\) sample of aluminium is stored in a laboratory. In a different laboratory, in the same town, there is a \(1\mathrm{kg}\) sample of iron.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 625, 663, 645]]<|/det|>
Which quantity must these two samples **always** have in common?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 654, 133, 672]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 655, 295, 672]]<|/det|>
the same density

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 680, 133, 698]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 680, 336, 698]]<|/det|>
the same temperature

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 707, 133, 725]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 707, 297, 725]]<|/det|>
the same volume

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 734, 133, 752]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 734, 292, 752]]<|/det|>
the same weight

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 71, 574, 92]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 101, 848, 139]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 147, 386, 166]]<|/det|>
What is the density of the liquid?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 180, 134, 201]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 178, 242, 203]]<|/det|>
40 \(\mathrm{g / cm^3}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 227, 133, 246]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 225, 242, 250]]<|/det|>
50 \(\mathrm{g / cm^3}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 272, 133, 291]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 268, 250, 294]]<|/det|>
120 \(\mathrm{g / cm^3}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 316, 133, 336]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 312, 250, 339]]<|/det|>
160 \(\mathrm{g / cm^3}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 375, 94, 393]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 375, 379, 393]]<|/det|>
A car moves along a level road.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 405, 645, 425]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows all of the horizontal forces acting on the car.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[170, 433, 826, 530]]<|/det|>

Which statement is correct?

<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 574, 358, 593]]<|/det|>
The car is slowing down.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 602, 131, 620]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 602, 346, 620]]<|/det|>
The car is speeding up.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 628, 131, 647]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 628, 472, 647]]<|/det|>
The car is moving at a constant speed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 655, 131, 673]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 655, 400, 673]]<|/det|>
The car is moving backwards.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 719, 92]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a force being applied to a lever to lift a heavy weight.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[215, 98, 781, 217]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 231, 761, 252]]<|/det|>
Which change would enable the heavy weight to be lifted with a smaller force?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 261, 134, 280]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 261, 376, 280]]<|/det|>
Move the force to the right.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 288, 133, 306]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 287, 443, 306]]<|/det|>
Move the heavy weight to the right.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 314, 133, 333]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 314, 364, 333]]<|/det|>
Move the force to the left.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 341, 133, 359]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 341, 364, 359]]<|/det|>
Move the pivot to the left.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 384, 96, 402]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 384, 475, 403]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a hydroelectric system.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 410, 888, 625]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 640, 524, 660]]<|/det|>
What are the main energy changes taking place?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 670, 134, 688]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 670, 598, 688]]<|/det|>
chemical energy \(\rightarrow\) kinetic energy \(\rightarrow\) electrical energy

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 696, 133, 714]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 696, 625, 714]]<|/det|>
electrical energy \(\rightarrow\) gravitational energy \(\rightarrow\) kinetic energy

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 724, 133, 742]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 724, 625, 742]]<|/det|>
gravitational energy \(\rightarrow\) kinetic energy \(\rightarrow\) electrical energy

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 751, 133, 769]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 751, 625, 769]]<|/det|>
kinetic energy \(\rightarrow\) electrical energy \(\rightarrow\) gravitational energy

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 106, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 819, 107]]<|/det|> An escalator (moving stairs) and a lift (elevator) are both used to carry passengers if underground railway platform up to street level. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[180, 112, 814, 390]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 405, 920, 440]]<|/det|> The escalator takes 20 seconds to carry a man to street level. The useful work done is \(W.\) The useful power developed is \(P.\) The lift takes 30 seconds to carry the same man to street level. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 451, 892, 470]]<|/det|> How much useful work is done by the lift, and how much useful power is developed by the lift? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 480, 510, 625]]<|/det|>
useful work
done by lift		useful power
developed by lift
Amore than \(W\)less than \(P\)
Bmore than \(W\)\(P\)
C\(W\)less than \(P\)
D\(W\)\(P\)
